p: Several lines of evidence point to a richness of DNA-level variation in S. halepense, including an abundance of novel coding sequences, much richer diversity of neutral DNA markers than its progenitors, and novel gene expression patterns exemplified by rhizome-enriched expression of some alleles from its non-rhizomatous S. bicolor progenitor. The spread of invasive taxa is much more rapid than migration in native taxa, and may require more genetic variation to sustain ( Lee, 2002). Although there is somewhat less variation near the invasion front than the center of its US distribution ( Sezen et al., 2016), rich S. halepense diversity may support its projected 200â€“600 km northward spread in the coming century ( McDonald et al., 2009).
